Award.AbstractNarration:
CAREER: Detection and Estimation in Complex and Uncertain Environments

NSF Proposal #1053932
PI: Jill Nelson

Statistical signal processing plays a fundamental role in fields as diverse as personal communications, national security, and medical image processing. To support the continued advancement of these fields and many others, there is a need to develop efficient near-optimal solutions to increasingly challenging detection and estimation problems. The focus of this research is addressing detection and estimation challenges in environments that exhibit high degrees of complexity and high levels of model uncertainty. In such scenarios, optimal detection and estimation solutions are often computationally infeasible, if not impossible, to determine. This research explores the effectiveness of tree search techniques, originally developed for sequential decoding, to address these challenges. The intellectual merit of the work is in the development of approximate detection and estimation algorithms that achieve near-optimal performance with dramatically reduced computational complexity requirements.

There are two primary technical objectives of this research. The first is to characterize the detection/estimation problem space for which tree search techniques provide competitive solutions through analysis of computational complexity as a function of system properties, and to frame conclusions in the context of existing results for competing approaches. The second objective is to develop and evaluate tree search approaches to three benchmark problems: channel estimation and data detection for broadly dispersive, rapidly varying channels; multiple transmitter location estimation for cognitive radio applications; and dynamic state estimation under model uncertainty or absence. The aims of the education component of this research are to design and implement elementary-level engineering curriculum centered around hands-on telecommunications activities, and to develop college-level problem-based learning curriculum that deepens students' understanding of probability and random processes by connecting abstract concepts to real-world problems with probabilistic models.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The focus of this project was the development of efficient near-optimal solutions to detection and estimation problems in environments that exhibit high degrees of complexity and high levels of model uncertainty. Such problems arise in fields as diverse as wireless communications, military surveillance, and medical image processing. We have used tree-search techniques, originally developed in the context of digital communications, to address these problems.  

We have developed and evaluated tree-search and related approaches to several timely detection and estimation challenges.

  • We have developed a computationally-efficient algorithm for blind sequential detection of data transmitted over sparse, dispersive communication channels.  In applications such as underwater acoustic communication and HDTV, data is transmitted over channels whose impulse responses may span hundreds of symbols, but only a fraction of the channel taps have significant energy. The tree-search based approach facilitates efficient data detection by exploiting the characteristics of sparse channels. The novel joint channel estimation and data detection technique combines tree search with a greedy algorithm for sparse channel estimation that operates in a per-survivor fashion along each path through the search tree.  Simulation results show that the proposed method not only reduces computational complexity compared to existing methods but also provides superior performance.
  • We have developed Bayesian tree-search techniques for dynamic state estimation under model uncertainty and applied these techniques to problems in target tracking. We have derived an analytical expression for the tree-search path metric in dynamic state estimation and used this result to develop a framework for characterizing how the probability of losing a target varies with parameters such as observation noise, probability of detection, and state space quantization.
  • We have developed cluster-based sequential algorithms for estimating the locations of multiple transmitters within a surveillance space based only on received signal strength as measured by a set of randomly distributed sensors. These results are applicable to cognitive radio, as estimates of transmitter locations provide valuable information in identifying white space in the radio spectrum. We have characterized the relationship between clustering performance and desired detection/false alarm rates as a function of shadowing noise.
  • We have developed a sequential algorithm for indoor localization using signal strength measurements from a collection of Wi-Fi access points, an example of dynamic state estimation under model uncertainty. The algorithm, which is built on a probabilistic framework and a set of training data collected offline, allows a user (typically a robot) unfamiliar with a building to navigate the building and perform self-localization using a simple map of the building and an associated map of expected received signal strengths from a select set of existing access points.
  • We have developed a sequential detection approach to perform computationally efficient music transcription from raw audio data. Tree search is combined with instance-based pitch classification to yield high transcription accuracy. Computation can be further reduced by incorporating prior musicological information. 

In the educational realm, the project focused on developing and implementing evidence-based practices for student-centered learning in both undergraduate and graduate signal processing and communications courses. We developed and implemented an undergraduate digital communications project in which students created an end-to-end model of a simple communications system. They then simulated the model in software and analyzed the relationship between theoretical and simulated performance results. In addition, we redesigned the software laboratory assignments in continuous and discrete-time signals and systems courses to center around real-world applications, include experiment design and extended inquiry, and build to a final project that synthesizes the material across the course. We also created and implemented a fully student-centered flipped classroom realization of a discrete-time signals and systems course. The course was taught in an active learning classroom in which students completed collaborative assignments that combined several course concepts and connected concepts to familiar applications.
